I.   INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In March 2004, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) accepted the administration of the 
Japan  Fund  for  Public  Policy  Training  (JFPPT),  which  aims  to  assist  developing  member 
countries’ (DMCs) institutions to build their capacities for public policy training and education, 
initially  concentrating  on  transition  economies  such  as  Viet  Nam.  Initially,  the  JFPPT  was 
administered  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  Institute.  However,  in  October  2005,  this 
responsibility was transferred to ADB with the current Southeast Asia Department (SERD) as the 
administrative focal point. On 2 December 2005, regional technical assistance (RETA) for the 
Public Policy Training Program (PPTP) 2006 in the amount of $950,000 was approved to support 
implementation of the activities in 2006.1 Lessons learned in implementing the first year of the 
Program under the first RETA, and consultations with the governments concerned—including 
Cambodia,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR),  and  Viet  Nam—resulted  in  the 
development of the proposed second RETA to support a multiyear PPTP for 2007–2010 for 
further implementation of the activities under the JFPPT. Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam all 
support the expansion of the PPTP activities. The enhancement of public policy training in these 
countries is expected to provide a solid contribution to strengthening the overall capacity of senior 
officials in efficiently managing their public administration systems. The proposed second RETA 
also responds to the request that the PPTP should help not only civil service officials but also 
senior government leaders in areas such as leadership management, dealing with mass media, 
addressing civil society, effective negotiations, and public governance. The design and monitoring 
framework is shown in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.   ISSUES 
 
2.  The three Mekong countries, Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam are all going through 
significant changes at various speeds from planned to market-oriented economy, from isolation to 
regional and global integration, and from rural agro-based to more balanced economies with an 
increasing share of industry and service sectors. For these transformations to succeed, the civil 
service staff in these countries need to be trained in areas and scale unprecedented before. The 
acceleration of regional integration among the GMS countries have added a further sense of 
urgency on the need to develop a well trained pool of civil service officials in all these three 
countries. 
 
3.  With their regional and global integration, all three transitional economies will be required  
to take increasingly more complex decisions so as to remain competitive and in compliance with 
the World Trade Organization (WTO) obligations. These decisions permeate all sectors ranging 
from  banking,  finance,  manufacturing,  foreign  trade,  fiscal  management  and  budgeting, 
international law, information technology, foreign language, among others. These countries are 
also exposed considerably more to the increased competition and shifting comparative advantage. 
Furthermore, with the opening of their economies, the policy instruments available to them for 
prudent macro economic management become fewer, making such management more difficult 
than when their economies were closed.  
  
4.  On an individual basis, Viet Nam’s sustained high growth, consistent annual increase in 
foreign direct investment (FDI), and its target of exiting from a low-income to a middle-income-
country by 2010 have all placed a severe strain on the country’s existing civil service system. Viet 
Nam is currently at a stage of development where the country’s existing capacity lags far behind

the  demand for efficient  civil  service  delivery,  timely  decision  making and  able  civil  service 
management from the business sector (domestic as well as foreign). The civil service system in 
the country remains ill-equipped and inadequate in terms of both quality and technical ability. 
There  is  an  acute  shortage  of  required  technical,  administrative  and  management  skills  in 
different areas and agencies both at national and provincial levels.  
 
5.  The problem of a weak civil service system is also prevalent in the case of Cambodia, 
having lost a generation of educated citizens in the aftermath of the civil war in the 1980s. With 
50% of the civil servants below the age of 40, Lao PDR also needs substantial strengthening of 
the administrative and technical staff in its civil service system. Both countries critically require 
modernization and professionalization of their respective civil service systems. 
 
6.  The civil service officials in Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam therefore need to be 
trained in a range of areas covering multiple disciplines. There are ongoing efforts to upgrade the 
countries’ existing pre-service civil service training institutions. However, in the case of in-service 
training for advanced and contemporary subjects, weaknesses exist particularly in the articulation 
of training needs, formulation of programs and effectiveness in delivery which highlight the urgent 
need for creating a mechanism for strengthening the civil service officials’ capacities in their 
functions. The lack of a modernized system in public policy training of middle to senior level civil 
service officials and limited opportunity for higher training on leadership and management need to 
be addressed as a matter of urgency. Accordingly, these countries made a strong request for 
ADB support.  The proposed RETA is intended to address these needs by helping establish 
effective  knowledge  networking  partnerships  between  these  transitional  economies  with  the 
outstanding public policy research and training institutions both within and outside of the region 
with the recognition that in each country there are also efforts to improve domestic institutions for 
civil service training particularly for pre-service training. There are also considerable interest 
among external public policy training and research institutions to extend assistance. The RETA, 
by facilitating the development of knowledge-exchange hubs and helping create core groups of 
trainees and trainers, will enable capacity build-up in the RETA countries on a long-term basis, in 
line with the goals and objectives of the JFPPT.  
 
III.   THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The RETA is designed to undertake full implementation of the PPTP during 2007–2010, 
following on from the start-up activities initiated under the TA 6277-REG. The full implementation 
will involve a number of activities—short-term and long-term, in country and abroad—all aimed at 
helping build sustained domestic institutional capacity in these countries. This will be undertaken 
through well-designed formal and informal in-service training programs for civil service officials at 
middle to senior levels. The programs will be initiated in Viet Nam and extended to Cambodia and 
the  Lao  PDR  as  appropriate.  The  RETA  will  also  provide  specialized  programs  for  senior 
government leaders on various technical and non-technical subjects.  
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The RETA will adopt a process approach whereby all the components of PPTP are 
designed and implemented in close consultation with key government agencies of the three 
countries. The courses to be selected and the contents to be covered will be developed based on 
the training needs assessment of respective ministries and agencies. They will be reviewed and

3 
endorsed, by the Advisory Committee in the case of Viet Nam (established under PPTP 2006) 
and by the counterpart agencies in the case of Cambodia and Lao PDR.  
 
9.  The key activities of the RETA include: (i) implementation of core competency courses in 
public policy for mid-career and senior level civil servants of Viet Nam; (ii) introduction of similar 
courses in Cambodia and Lao PDR; (iii) a fellowship program to send outstanding candidates for 
formal degree courses overseas; and (iv) a teaching support component to develop case studies 
and best practice cases and other learning materials with national and regional content.  
 
10.  One  of  the  major  RETA  activities  in  Viet  Nam  will  include  an  exclusive  leadership 
management program customized for senior government leaders. The leadership program will 
include managing media, dealing with civil society, effective negotiation skills, English language 
skills, international law, public good governance, and an anticorruption program. The leadership 
program will last 10–15 days and be implemented initially as a pilot program in early 2008. 
 
11.  A multiyear structured series of short- and medium-term courses will constitute the next 4 
years of the Program (2007–2010). The implementation of core courses will be carried out in 
batches  of  about  100  participants,  trained  in  classes  of  no  larger  than  35  students  each. 
Additional  courses  and  programs  that  address  specific  economic,  public  administration  and 
leadership skills will also be offered in line with the expressed requests of the line ministries. By 
early 2008, about three batches of participants from the three countries will have completed the 
training course in public policy designed for their countries. All of these courses will be conducted 
in local languages through translation. 
 
12.  Core courses will run for succeeding years through 2010 for three or more batches 
annually, each batch consisting of about 100 participants in Viet Nam. Seminars will also be 
offered and capacity building programs will be continued in Cambodia and Lao PDR. At the end 
of 4 years, it is expected that the PPTP will have graduated over 12 batches of participants who 
have  undertaken  various  public  policy  training  programs,  and  substantially  more  with  the 
participants in specialized courses. The minimum projected number of alumni after 4 years is 
expected to be around 1,800–2,000—including 1,100–1,200 Vietnamese senior civil servants and 
700–800 senior civil servants from Cambodia and Lao PDR.  
 
13.  A public policy fellows program will be awarded to 25 outstanding PPTP graduates for 
formal higher degree training courses. The candidates will be selected on a highly competitive 
basis by a selection committee composed of government representatives (represented in the 
steering committee); PPTP program manager; and Viet Nam Resident Mission (VRM), ADB. A list 
of accredited overseas institutions will serve as partner institutions, and they will be selected on 
the basis of their global reputation in public policy education. 
 
14.  Under the RETA, the resource center for public policy will be established and reinforced 
(as appropriate) in each of the three countries with the resource materials, case studies,  relevant 
technical documents and other necessary equipment to serve the participants in the training 
courses. Each center will be designed as an integral part of the PPTP with the aim of meeting the 
needs  of  participants  for  independent  and  group  research  to  support  their  overall  learning 
experiences. A teaching support component will be developed to generate teaching materials in 
public policy that are relevant to the contexts of the three countries and which can be tapped by 
their respective training institutes for future programs. The training materials and equipment will 
be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007 as amended from time to 
time) and will be provided to the country resource centers. The materials and equipment will be 
transferred to each RETA country upon RETA completion. In order to ensure that the long-term

4   
institutional benefits of the RETA are sustained, assurances have been obtained that (i) the 
training materials and the training programs to be prepared under the RETA will be extensively 
used  for  further  training  of  the  new  batches  of  civil  service  officials  even  after  the  RETA 
completion; (ii)  the knowledge networking to be established under the RETA with the various 
regional/international institutions will be retained and further developed through frequent contacts 
and/or visits; and (iii) the training facilities, programs and materials and other equipment to be 
handed over to the countries upon RETA completion will receive maximum care for their proper 
maintenance and subsequent training uses.  
 
15.  It is important that the PPTP training programs are properly assessed and evaluated on a 
continuing basis to allow appropriate adjustments, using feedback from interim results in the 
teaching and learning approaches. This will ensure that the objectives of the programs are 
achieved  effectively  and  efficiently.  Feedback  will  be  obtained  from  participants  as  well  as 
resource  institutions  on  each  activity  under  PPTP  so  that  any  necessary  adjustments  are 
undertaken in real time, thereby increasing the overall efficiency of the entire training program.  
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $21.4 million over a period of 4 years, of which 
$17.8 million will be financed on a grant basis by the JFPPT funded by the Government of Japan 
and administered by ADB. The balance of $3.6 million will be financed from the governments of 
Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam in the form of cash and kind. A breakdown of costs is shown 
in Appendix 2.  
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  VRM will be the Executing Agency of the RETA and will be responsible for the overall 
RETA  administration.  An  international  expert  will  be  engaged  to  act  as  program  manager, 
overseeing  the  training  program  design  and  in  ensuring  that  implementation  is  carried  out 
efficiently, while taking into account governments’ views and comments. The program manager 
will be assisted by an advisor and a small group of technical and support staff carried over from 
the earlier RETA, and will report to the Country Director, VRM (Appendix 3). The program 
manager,  advisor,  and  technical  experts  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The Advisory Committee, set up in Viet Nam under the PPTP 2006 will be retained. 
However, in addition to the original members, it will be expanded to include a senior official from 
the  Central  Organization  Committee.  To  provide  the  necessary  support  to  the  effective 
functioning of the Viet Nam Advisory Committee, the existing Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) 
Secretariat in the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) will also act as the Secretariat for the 
Advisory Committee. The functions of the Advisory Committee and its Secretariat in Viet Nam are 
shown in Appendix 4. The utilization of the existing Secretariat will relieve MPI of additional 
administrative burden and enhance the complementarities between the ongoing GMS program 
and the proposed RETA. In view of the expected increased workload, the secretariat coordinator 
will be assisted initially by one additional middle level staff and two more junior staff in carrying 
out administrative and other related activities. As the PPTP activities from the proposed RETA 
expand  further,  the  Secretariat  may  need  one  additional  middle  level  staff  and  two  more 
supporting staff during the later years of the PPTP implementation.  
 
19.  The program manager will (i) hold regular consultations with the secretariat coordinator (in 
the case of Viet Nam) and other relevant officials of Cambodia and Lao PDR; and (ii) ensure that

5 
the training programs and other RETA activities fully reflect the governments’ required training 
needs and aspirations through close consultation. While the Advisory Committee is created in 
Viet Nam, on initial consultations in Cambodia and Lao PDR, it was not felt necessary to develop 
parallel structures in those countries as their respective civil service training programs could be 
fully coordinated through existing assistance channels.  
 
20.  An inter-country steering committee composed of one national coordinator from each of 
the RETA countries will be established to coordinate the functioning of the PPTP activities. The 
national coordinator to be nominated by their respective governments could be an official already 
working as the GMS national coordinator for ensuring and reinforcing the complementarities of 
PPTP with the ongoing Phnom Penh Plan. The program manager and Country Director, VRM, 
will also be members of this committee. The national coordinators will function as the focal points 
in each country. The steering committee will meet periodically to review the RETA progress, 
address any regional issues as they arise, and ensure smooth and timely implementation the 
RETA. 
 
21.  For the actual design and delivery of the multi-disciplinary training programs, the RETA 
will engage selected outstanding public policy research/training institutions within and outside the 
region. Given that the RETA is meant to help create sustained long-term, in-house institutional 
capacity for public policy training in the RETA countries, facilitating the networking and twinning 
arrangements with reputable regional and international institutions with the domestic demands is 
considered a key. Resorting to various short-term international consultants, as under the PPTP 
2006, has been found to be less effective since such an approach is unlikely to leave behind 
sustainable long-term institutional ties in these countries. Support of regional and international 
institutions for the leadership programs and public policy training activities and related services 
under the RETA is to be secured through single source selection of outstanding institutions with 
demonstrated credibility and a record of excellence in their fields. Such institutions would have 
extensive relevant experience in different countries within the region. Such an approach will help 
RETA countries establish long-term institutional linkages with these international and regional 
institutions and help establish the desired capacity buildup in these countries on a long-term basis. 
 
22.  Sample terms of reference of such partner institutions are shown in Appendix 5. The 
assignment of such institutions will be up to 36 months each, staggered over a 4-year period 
(2007–2010). A number of national consultants and/or universities/research institutes will also be 
recruited in the three countries for the design and delivery of the training program and the 
preparation of case studies for a total number of 170 person-months (90 person-months for Viet 
Nam  and  40  person-months  each  for  Cambodia  and  Lao  PDR).  They  will  be  selected  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
23.  In developing and executing the component relating to the leadership program for senior 
leaders,  the  services  of  contracted  institutions  could  also  be  supplemented  by  additional 
international institutes/universities or individuals as appropriate. Such flexibility is expected to 
enhance the effectiveness of the leadership program given the exclusive nature of the component. 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
24.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $17.8 million to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Public Policy Training for the Public Policy Training Program 2007–2010.

Program Manager

and manage its day-to-day implementation under the supervision of the Country Director of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) Viet Nam Resident Mission. The consultant will be responsible 
for tasks identified below and will be stationed in Hanoi, Viet Nam at the PPTP resource center. 
He/she will be supported by an Advisor, and by program officers (domestic consultants) and 
administrative assistance to be recruited locally in Viet Nam.  
 
  Key  tasks  and  responsibilities.  The  key  tasks  and  responsibilities  of  Program 
Manager will include but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Take responsibility for overall development and implementation of the Public 
Policy Training Program (PPTP) under the guidance of the inter-country steering 
committee and Advisory Committee and its secretariat for Viet Nam, and the 
counterpart  agencies  of  Cambodia  and  Lao  PDR,  including  identification  of 
courses,  their  design  and  implementation  in  collaboration  with  the  partner 
institutions. 
   
(ii)  Review existing reports and documents related to public policy, and help assess 
public policy training needs to identify potential subject areas that need to be 
covered by PPTP. 
 
(iii)  Under the guidance of Country Director, VRM, help organize the inter-country 
steering committee meeting. 
 
(iv)  Coordinate  closely  with  the  Advisory  Committee  Secretariat,  set  up  in  the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment in the case of Viet Nam, to help facilitate the 
implementation  of  PPTP  in  Viet  Nam,  and  assist  in  organizing  the  Advisory 
Committee meeting. 
 
(v)  Coordinate closely with the counterpart agencies in Cambodia and Lao PDR for 
the  implementation  of  PPTP  activities  in  both  countries  and  help  deliver 
programs. 
 
(vi)  Liaise and network with government ministries and agencies, universities, think 
tanks, research and academic institutions  to identify best priority subject areas

(vii)  Contact potential partnership institutions to collect data and information on the

Advisor to the Program Manager 
 
  Overall Responsibility. The international consultant (Advisor) will assist the Program 
Manger in the implementation of PPTP including day to day implementation and administration 
of the activities under the RETA. The Advisor will assist Program Manager in all aspects of 
PPTP implementation, but will be specifically responsible for administration and management 
including budgeting, financial management and control, human resource management, contract 
management,  facilities  management,  logistics,  and  monitoring,  reporting  and  record 
management.   
 
  Key  tasks  and  responsibilities.  The key tasks and responsibilities of Advisor will 
include but not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Assist  Program  Manger  in  the  implementation of  PPTP,  and  ensure  that  all 
activities  will  be  implemented  in  accordance  with  the  pertinent  ADB  rules, 
regulations and guidelines on various aspects of management and control.  
 
(ii)  Help Program Manager in the organization of the inter-country steering meeting 
as well as Viet Nam Advisory Committee including the preparation of the relevant 
papers for discussion. 
 
(iii)  Help  ensure  that  PPTP  and  its  staff  will  have  effective  communication  with 
various stakeholders. 
 
(iv)  Help Program Manger in budgeting, financial management and control, human 
resource management, contract management, facilities management, logistics, 
and  monitoring,  reporting  and record management for  the  implementation  of 
PPTP. 
 
(v)  Assist  Program  Manager  in  developing  knowledge  networks  to  promote 
institutional twinning. 
 
(vi)  Assist  Program  Manager  in  the  responsibilities  relating  to  reporting  and 
information dissemination. 
 
(vii)  Perform other tasks as may be required for successful implementation of PPTP.

Appendix 4  11 
FUNCTIONS OF THE VIET NAM ADVISORY COMMITTEE AND ITS SECRETARIAT 
 
A.  Advisory Committee: 
 
1.   The Viet Nam Advisory Committee will be represented by senior government officials 
from major line agencies of Viet Nam as implemented in 2006 under RETA 6277-REG. In 
addition, the Committee will also include a senior official representing the Central Organization 
Committee. The Committee’s functions will include, but not be limited to the following: 
 
            (i)  Provide strategic guidance to all concerned parties to ensure smooth and timely 
implementation and maximum effectiveness of the RETA activities in Viet Nam. 
(ii)  Endorse the list of ministries and agencies and the candidates for various types 
of public policy training programs for Viet Nam. 
(iii)  Review, comment on, and approve the courses/subjects identified for training 
and the contents developed for each course for Viet Nam participants.  
(iv)  Assess and endorse the list of candidates nominated, on a competitive basis, for 
formal higher degree training abroad with respect to Vietnamese candidates.  
(v)  Provide guidance, from time to time, on any other issues as they emerge with 
regard to PPTP implementation pertaining to Viet Nam. 
 
B.  Viet Nam Advisory Committee Secretariat 
 
2.   The Viet Nam Advisory Committee Secretariat provides necessary support to the Viet 
Nam  Advisory  Committee  so  that  it  can  function  effectively  and  efficiently.  The  Viet  Nam 
Advisory  Committee  Secretariat  will  also  act  as  the  focal  point  in  coordinating  proper 
implementation of all RETA related activities pertaining to Viet Nam. Its functions will include, 
among others, the following: 
 
(i)  Function as the arm of the Viet Nam Advisory Committee and focal point for 
coordinating PPTP activities on behalf of the Government of Viet Nam. 
(ii)  Ensure  smooth  and  timely  implementation,  in  close  coordination  with  the 
program manager, of PPTP activities through coordination and support. 
(iii)  Prepare list of candidates for various types of training programs for submission to 
the Viet Nam Advisory Committee for endorsement with regard to the programs 
relating to Viet Nam. 
(iv)    Prepare list of equipment required for the efficient functioning of the Viet Nam 
Advisory Committee Secretariat. 
(v)  Prepare list of competent national consultants and national universities/research 
institutes, and assist the Viet Nam Resident Mission in selecting the national 
experts/institutes as required.    
(vi)  Organize Viet Nam Advisory Committee meetings by proper scheduling, ensuring 
the proper invitation and attendance of all committee members. 
(vii)  Help organize workshops, seminars, and training classes in coordination with the 
program manager. 
(viii)  Help  carry  out  translation  of  various  training  materials  and  other  resource 
materials into Vietnamese. 
(ix)  Help organize the inter-country steering committee meeting. 
(x)  Represent Viet Nam at the inter-country steering committee meeting. 
(xi)  Undertake any other matters as required by the Viet Nam Advisory Committee.

12   Appendix 5   
 
SAMPLE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF THE PARTNER INSTITUTIONS 
 
A.  Institution A 
 
1.   The outstanding international and regional institute(s) to be selected to carry out the 
RETA  related  training  and  other  similar  activities  would  have  demonstrated  credibility  and 
excellent performance record in designing and delivering programs relevant to the RETA. Such 
institutes would have extensive relevant experiences in different countries in the region in 
particular the RETA countries. Responsibilities of the partner institutions to be engaged under 
the RETA include: 
 
 (i)  Carry  out  surveys/interviews  with  the  identified  line  ministries/agencies,  and 
develop generic training needs assessment for them. 
(ii)  Analyze  and  design  detailed  customized  curriculum  for  training  and  skills 
upgrading programs based on the training needs assessment of each ministry 
and  agency  as  selected  by  PPTP  in  consultation  with  the  governments 
concerned. 
(iii)  Deliver  customized  training  to  the  identified  candidates  from  selected  line 
ministries/agencies in coordination with the relevant country authorities (i.e., in 
the case of Viet Nam, it will be Viet Nam Advisory Committee Secretariat) and 
the program manager. 
(iv)  Prepare  case  studies,  best  practice  notes  and  other  relevant  materials  for 
workshops, lectures, and other activities in support of PPTP activities.  
(vi)  Evaluate the training methodology and the materials used in the training program 
continuously;  obtain  feedback  and  regularly  adjust/modify  and  improve  the 
training methodology and materials used in the training programs for enhanced 
efficiency.  
(vii)  Build  pool  of  relevant  training  materials  that  could  be  used  by  the  regional 
technical assistance (RETA) countries’ training institutions in their future training 
programs.  
(viii)  Make necessary arrangements for the top performing participants selected for 
higher level training programs in (a) identifying universities, (b) enrolment-related 
requirements, and (c) other logistical support.  
(ix)  Develop customized special programs particularly suited to the senior leaders of 
the  RETA  countries  in  areas  proposed  by  the  Government  and  undertake 
leadership programs for them.  
(x)  Undertake any other PPTP activities as required. 
 
B.  Institution B 
 
2.   The international and regional outstanding institute(s) to be selected to carry out the 
RETA  related  training  and  other  similar  activities  would  have  demonstrated  credibility  and 
excellent  performance  record  in  areas  relevant  to  the  RETA.  Such  institutes  would  have 
extensive relevant experiences in different countries in the region including Cambodia, Lao PDR 
or Viet Nam as appropriate. Activities of the institution will include: 
 
(i)  Prepare policy related papers as relevant and required for use in the public policy 
training programs.

Appendix 5  13 
(ii)  Help prepare and train the policy and decision makers in issues of national 
importance relating to compliance with World Trade Organization requirements 
and their impact on the national economy. 
(iii)  Prepare training courses on complex international trade related issues and their 
implications  on  the  national  economy,  and  deliver  training  programs  to 
government officials. 
(iv)  Develop training materials aimed at familiarizing government officials with anti-
dumping related issues, and ways and means to handle them. 
(v)  Design and deliver training courses on dispute resolution arising from issues 
related to the World Trade Organization to adequately equip government officials 
in encountering such situations. 
(vi)  Help identify accredited universities for higher degree formal training for highly 
qualified PPTP candidates selected on a competitive basis. 
(vii)  Help establish resource centers in the RETA countries with relevant training 
materials, reflecting the national and regional contents for use in future training 
programs and for research purposes. 
(viii)  Undertake any other tasks required for the effective implementation of the PPTP.
